Role_Model_Context: Indian international cricketer and former national team captain.
Situation_Faced: He went through depression during the 2014 England tour after repeated batting failures.
Challenge_Narrative: Kohli described waking up every day believing he would not score runs and feeling completely out of control of his game. Despite being surrounded by teammates, he felt emotionally isolated and like the “loneliest guy in the world.” He recognized that the absence of professional mental-health support made the experience even harder.
Key_Action_Taken: He openly admitted his depression and emphasized the need for professional support for athletes.
Key_Quote_or_Insight: “I felt like I was the loneliest guy in the world.”
Summary_Psychological: Kohli's story illustrates how performance failure can quickly erode self-worth when tied too tightly to identity. His openness breaks stigma and shows that even elite performers can experience deep emotional lows. Seeking professional help is a strength, not a weakness.
Outcome_Resolution: He recovered his form later and became a public voice advocating athlete mental-health awareness.
